item.title: Warhammer Survivors is an officially licensed Vampire Survivors game, coming 2026
item.content:encoded:
Auroch Digital has just announced Warhammer Survivors, a new Rogue-Like Survivors game created with the blessing of both Warhammer and Poncle (Vampire Survivors). It's set to release sometime in 2026.

The game, much like Vampire Survivors, will feature endless hordes of Warhammer enemies, which you must take down with a variety of weapons and playable characters. You'll be able to choose between the grimdark universe of Warhammer 40k, or the fantastical Warhammer: Age of Sigmar, each with their own unlocks to pursue.

40K characters revealed include Malum Caedo from another beloved Auroch Digital Warhammer game, Warhammer 40,000: Boltgun. There's also Cadian soldier Trooper Kozlowski, as well as Space Marine Intercessor Brother Luca. Warhammer: Age of Sigmar fans can look forward to playing Neave Blacktalon, Gotrek Gurnisson, and Sharynn Azurwrath.

There are some fun Easter eggs in there too for Warhammer fans, including Nuln Oil paint (a trusty Warhammer shade paint handy for pretty much everything) which will seemingly be an item you can use to fend off encroaching enemies. There's apparently going to be a vast roster of similar treats for fans of the franchise, so keep an eye out.

The game is available on Steam, and can be wishlisted now. There's no word on when exactly in 2026 it'll be released, but more announcements regarding Warhammer Survivors are on the way, so it's certainly worth keeping tabs on in the coming months.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/warhammer-survivors-is-an-officially-licensed-vampire-survivors-game-coming-2026

item.title: ARC Raiders Sales Estimates Range from 1.6 to 1.9 Million Units on Steam Alone
item.content:encoded:
Following a successful final beta event, Embark's ARC Raiders launched to excellent initial figures, easily surpassing the concurrent user peak reached by the studio's previous game, The Finals, which is even more impressive given that the latter is a free-to-play game, whereas the former is not.

This past weekend, the third-person PvPvE extraction shooter even surpassed that peak, settling around 354K concurrent players two days ago, an absolutely respectable figure that currently places the game at the 38th spot in Steam's all-time chart.

What really matters to game developers is sales, though, and there's good news on that front, too. According to estimates based on SteamDB data, ARC Raiders might have already sold between 1.6 million units (as estimated by Gamalytic) and 1.9 million units (as tracked by VG Insights and PlayTracker). Considering that the game is also available on the Epic Games Store, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series S|X, it's not inconceivable that it might have sold close to three million units by now in total. Sure, the $40 budget price helps, but many shooter fans had already spent $70 on Battlefield 6 a couple of weeks ago, and yet they deemed it worth spending more money on this one as well.

While we wait for official sales figures from Embark, the studio has already shared the post-launch roadmap for ARC Raiders. Later this month, players can look forward to a new map called Stella Montis, new Quests and gameplay items, new Arc machines (Matriarch and Shredder), and a community unlock event. In December, the developers will introduce more Quests, a new Raider deck, the Snowfall map condition, an event titled 'Flickering Flames', and the Expedition departure window. Other ongoing improvements without a specific timeframe include new feats and trials, more map conditions, cosmetics, and quality of life updates.

Follow Wccftech on Google or add us as a preferred source, to get our news coverage and reviews in your feeds.



https://wccftech.com/arc-raiders-sales-estimates-range-1-6-1-9-million-units-on-steam/

item.title: Nintendo‚Äôs Sold Over 10 Million Switch 2s, Twice As Fast As The PS5
item.content:encoded:
Nintendo has announced that its brand new console, the Switch 2, has now sold over 10 million units in the first four months on sale. That makes it the most successful console launch ever by quite some margin. And the two flagship games, Mario Kart World and Donkey Kong Bananza, each have their own extraordinary figures to boast of.

The Switch 2, launched June 5 after a peculiar and obfuscated build-up, went on to sell an extraordinary 3.5 million units in just its first four days on sale. Now, obviously that number includes pre-orders that built up rather chaotically from April, on top of post-launch sales in the opening days, so it was always going to be the most dramatic number. At the start of August, Nintendo revealed things were still going extremely well, with a total of six million Switch 2s sold in its first month. While numbers from rival console manufacturers are often more hazy, this fully confirms the hybrid gaming device as the most successful console launch ever, dwarfing the already impressive numbers of the original Switch, and beating the PS5 to 10 million sales by a full four months. Which is to say, the Switch 2 has sold twice as fast as Sony‚Äôs behemoth.

Come the latest financial filings from Nintendo, noting sales up to the end of September, the company reports that by September 30 it had sold a total of 10.36 million Switch 2s. Which is astonishing.

Meanwhile, Mario Kart World has nearly doubled its sales since its first month, with a total of 9.57 million copies sold (and that‚Äôs actually sold, rather than just shipped), while July 17‚Äôs Donkey Kong Bananza has shifted 3.49 million carts.

All these massive numbers have given Nintendo cause to increase its sales expectations for the end of the financial year. It was originally banking on 15 million Switch 2s sold by the spring, but that hope has now been raised to 19 million. Even this may still be a cautious under-estimation, given we‚Äôre just now entering the holiday season‚Äîa time period most rival consoles deliberately launch directly into. On top of that, the Switch 2 has already sold for two more months after these reported numbers, and with Nintendo‚Äôs plan to flood the stores with stock for Christmas, ‚Äúonly‚Äù another 8.5 million units by March 2026 could easily be reached.

Nintendo also announced that it has sold 1.89 million more original Switches in the same time period, and made a mind-blowing 61.56 million software sales across those six months. The Switch 2, with its far smaller user-base, still sold 20.62 million games, although as you will note, three fifths of that is made up of two games!



https://kotaku.com/switch-2-sales-nintendo-10-million-mario-kart-world-2000641025

item.title: Amazon Clears Out This 20,000mAh 87W 3-Port Power Bank, Now Selling for Pennies
item.content:encoded:
You know that sinking feeling when your phone hits 10% battery and you‚Äôre nowhere near an outlet? Or when you‚Äôre at the airport and every charging station is packed with people camping around power strips? A good power bank solves that problem but most of them either charge too slowly, run out of juice after one phone charge, or force you to carry a bunch of cables.

Anker just dropped the price on their 20,000mAh power bank with a built-in USB-C cable down to $44 from the usual $69 on Amazon. This thing pushes 87W across three devices at once and can charge a MacBook Pro to 50% in under 40 minutes.

See at Amazon

Power That Keeps Up With Your Day

That 20,000mAh capacity gives you multiple full charges for your phone or enough juice to top up a laptop when you‚Äôre working remotely and can‚Äôt find a seat near an outlet. In real terms, that‚Äôs four charges for an iPhone 17 or enough to fully charge your MacBook Air and still have juice for your phone and earbuds. The battery pack itself recharges in just 1.5 hours when you plug it into a 65W charger which means you‚Äôre not waiting around all night for it to be ready the next morning.

That all changes with its built-in USB-C cable: You won‚Äôt be rummaging around in your bag for the correct cable or realize it was still lying on your desk at home. Simply pull out the power bank, unwind the cable and plug in your device-done. It charges an iPhone 17 Pro to 58% in 30 minutes, or a MacBook Air to 52% over the same time, which is fast enough to get you through the rest of your workday or a particularly long flight.

The 87W total output splits across three ports with a single device maxing out at 65W. That means you can fast-charge your laptop through the USB-C port while your phone and wireless earbuds charge from the other two ports at the same time. The setup works for anything: iPhones, Samsung phones, iPads, Nintendo Switch, or any USB-C device you‚Äôre carrying around.

Anker designed this power bank to meet airline regulations so you can toss it in your carry-on without any drama at security. The 20,000mAh capacity sits right at the limit most airlines allow and gives you maximum power without crossing into the restricted zone.

For $44, you‚Äôre getting a power bank that actually covers the situations where you really do need backup power: long travel days, outdoor events, working from coffee shops, or just the peace of mind that your devices won‚Äôt die when you need them most. The 18-month warranty supports it so if anything goes wrong, you are covered.

item.title: This High-Spec HP Laptop (4TB SSD, 64GB RAM) Is 70% Off and Selling for Pennies, Amazon Clears Final Stock
item.content:encoded:
Laptops with serious power usually carry a price tag equal to a small fortune. You know how it goes: you look at the specs you actually need, check the price, and immediately start compromising. Maybe you don‚Äôt really need that much storage, right? Well, HP just threw an early Black Friday sale on Amazon that changes the game completely. This 17.3-inch laptop comes with 64GB of RAM, a 4TB SSD, and an AMD Ryzen 5 processor-basically the kind of setup that normally runs close to $4,000. The good new is that right now, it‚Äôs sitting at $1,199 after a 70% discount.

See at Amazon

The 17.3-inch touchscreen gives you breathing room that smaller laptops just can‚Äôt match: If you have ever tried to work on a 13-inch screen and felt you were playing Tetris with your windows, you will appreciate the reason size matters in this respect. The HD+ anti-glare panel means you can set up near a window without spending half your day adjusting the angle of the screen so that you can actually see what you‚Äôre doing. The touchscreen aspect really does speed things up when scrolling through long documents or just generally navigating about Windows 11 Pro.

Specs That Matter in Real Life

The Ryzen 5 7430U processor runs 6 cores and 12 threads and hits speeds up to 4.3GHz when you need it. In plain English, this means you can video call your team while updating a presentation with Slack pinging in the background and your music playing without your laptop freezing up or fans screaming like a jet engine. The integrated Radeon Graphics handle streaming and everyday visual tasks without breaking a sweat. It‚Äôs not a gaming rig, but it covers everything most people actually do on their computers day in and day out.

But here‚Äôs where it gets interesting: 64GB of RAM is absurd for most laptops and that is precisely why it‚Äôs so great. Most computers ship with 8GB or maybe 16GB, which forces you into this constant dance of closing programs to free up memory. With 64GB, you just stop thinking about it: Keep your email open all week, run that resource-hungry video editing software, open 50 browser tabs for your research project and the laptop just handles it.

The 4TB SSD storage means you are done with that ‚Äúdelete old files to install new programs‚Äù routine. Your whole photo collection from the last decade, work projects, personal files, software and backups can all live on one drive. And SSDs load everything faster than old hard drives so your programs open in seconds instead of you watching that spinning wheel for what feels like forever.

In Windows 11 Pro, there is Microsoft Copilot, the AI tool that helps draft emails, summarize long documents, or even brainstorm ideas when you‚Äôre stuck. Built-in AI image features let you edit photos without downloading extra software. Windows Hello logs you in via facial recognition which means no more typing passwords every time you open your laptop.

At $1,199 for this configuration, you‚Äôre getting a laptop that doesn‚Äôt force you to choose between the features you want versus the ones you can afford.

item.title: U.S. Patent Office Boss Orders Reexamination of Nintendo's Controversial 'Summon Character and Let It Fight' Pok√©mon Patent, Which IP Lawyer Claims 'F
item.content:encoded:
The director of the United States Patent and Trademark Office has ordered a reexamination of Nintendo's controversial 'summon character and let it fight' Pok√©mon patent after it was heavily criticized by IP lawyers.

In September, IP lawyers criticized the U.S. patent system and the USPTO after Nintendo was awarded a Pok√©mon patent that revolves around summoning a character and letting it fight.

Games Fray reported that Patent No. 12,403,397, dubbed the '397 patent, was granted by the USPTO "without any objection‚Äù to Nintendo, which is embroiled in ongoing litigation with Pocketpair's Palworld.

While the patent sums up how Pok√©mon games work in that you summon Pok√©mon to battle other Pok√©mon in the hope of adding them to your collection, there are countless other games that use similar mechanics, such as Persona, Digimon, and even Elden Ring, depending upon how the patent is interpreted.

At the time, IP expert Florian Mueller took to social media to say Nintendo ‚Äúshould never‚Äù have received a "summon character and let it fight" patent in the first place, while video game patent lawyer Kirk Sigmon told PC Gamer "these claims were in no way allowable."

Now, Games Fray has reported that Donald Trump nominee John A. Squires, who only became director of the USPTO in September, has personally ordered a reexamination after he "determined that substantial new questions of patentability have arisen" to certain claims made by the patent.

Here's Squires' description of the claims in question:

"The '397 patent issued with claims drawn to controlling the movement of a player character in a field of a virtual space, causing a sub character to appear in the field, controlling a battle in a manual mode when an enemy character is present in the location the sub character has appeared, and when an enemy character is not present in the location the sub character has appeared, automatically moving the sub character, and controlling a battle in an automatic mode when an enemy character is placed at a designated location."

In his order, Squires pointed to two older U.S. patent applications ‚Äî one filed by Konami in 2002, the other by Nintendo itself in 2019 ‚Äî as ‚Äúprior art‚Äù references. Both, Squires said, would be ‚Äúimportant in deciding whether the claims are patentable,‚Äù and each ‚Äúraises a substantial new question of patentability.‚Äù

Mueller, writing for Games Fray, said Squires' order was down to the ‚Äúpublic outrage‚Äù at the award of the patent, and concerns about the reputation of the U.S. patent system as a whole. While this reexamination isn‚Äôt a revocation order, Mueller insisted it is now ‚Äúhighly likely‚Äù that the USPTO will revoke Nintendo‚Äôs ‚Äò397 patent. Nintendo has two months to respond.

The Best Pok√©mon Spin-off Games

What does this mean for Nintendo and The Pok√©mon Company‚Äôs high-profile legal battle with Pocketpair over Palworld? Mueller said it ‚Äúfurther undermines the credibility‚Äù of Nintendo‚Äôs patent assertions against Pocketpair's game.

This is the latest legal blow for Nintendo in its battle against Palworld. Last month, one of the Nintendo patents related to its monster capture patents filed last year was rejected by the Japan Patent Office (JPO) for lacking originality. The office‚Äôs reasoning for the rejection made reference to older games with similar mechanics that were released even before 2021, including ARK (released in 2015), Monster Hunter 4 (2013), and Japanese browser game Kantai Collection (also 2013). Ironically, Pocketpair‚Äôs Craftopia (2020) and Niantic‚Äôs Pok√©mon Go (2016) were among other examples of games that were used to argue that the patent lacks originality.

The case involves three main patents granted by the JPO: two related to monster capture and release, and one related to riding characters. All three patents were filed in 2024, after Palworld came out. However, they are actually derived from earlier Nintendo patents dating from 2021. In other words, it seems that once Palworld came on the scene, Nintendo filed divisional patents that were geared to fight specifically against Palworld‚Äôs alleged infringement of the original patents.

Since then, Pocketpair has made changes to Palworld‚Äôs disputed mechanics. The November 2024 patch removed the ability to summon Pals by throwing Pok√©ball-like Pal Spheres (now Pals just materialize next to you when summoned). In May this year, another Palworld update changed how you can glide in the game ‚Äî instead of directly grabbing onto Glider Pals, now you just simply use Pal-buffed Glider equipment. The case has rumbled on, with Nintendo even rewriting a mount-related patent mid-lawsuit, and arguing that mods should not count as prior art.

So what happens next? Mueller said there may not be any further developments this calendar year relating to Nintendo‚Äôs lawsuit against Pocketpair or patents that are related to it. But decisions are expected next year. All eyes will be on Presiding Judge Motoyuki Nakashima, who leads the patent division of the Tokyo District Court. ‚ÄúIt is ever more likely that Nintendo will lose,‚Äù Mueller said.

At the Game Developers Conference (GDC) in March, IGN sat down for an extended conversation with John ‚ÄúBucky‚Äù Buckley, communications director and publishing manager for Palworld developer Pocketpair. We spoke following his talk at the conference, 'Community Management Summit: A Palworld Roller Coaster: Surviving the Drop.' During that talk, Buckley went into candid detail about a number of Palworld‚Äôs struggles, especially the accusations of it using generative AI (which Pocketpair has since debunked pretty soundly) and stealing Pokemon‚Äôs models for its own Pals (a claim that the person who originally made it has since retracted). He even commented a bit on Nintendo‚Äôs patent infringement lawsuit against the studio, saying it ‚Äúcame as a shock‚Äù to the studio and was ‚Äúsomething that no one even considered.‚Äù

Last month, former Capcom game developer Yoshiki Okamoto issued comments seemingly against Pocketpair and Palworld in the legal battle, sparking a backlash from viewers. In a YouTube video posted on his channel on September 27, Okamoto said Palworld had "crossed a line that should not be crossed, and I don't want the world to become a place where this kind of thing is acceptable."

Photo by Tomohiro Ohsumi/Getty Images.

Wesley is Director, News at IGN. Find him on Twitter at @wyp100. You can reach Wesley at wesley_yinpoole@ign.com or confidentially at wyp100@proton.me.

item.title: Nintendo Raises Hardware Forecast as Switch 2 Sales Hit 10.36 Million, Continuing Streak as the Biggest Console Launch of All Time
item.content:encoded:
Nintendo Switch 2 has sold an astonishing 10.36 million units in six months, a record-breaking amount that sees the platform continue its run as the biggest console launch ever.

In its latest financial results, published this morning, Nintendo raised its hardware forecast for the year in response to the Switch 2's spectacular performance. It now expects to shift 19 million units of its new console before the end of March 2026.

To put Switch 2's success into perspective, Nintendo has doubled the launch sales of Switch 1 (which sold 4.7 million units in its first six months back in 2017) and is also well ahead of the PlayStation 5's own impressive arrival (which sold 7.8 million units back in November 2020, though was limited by stock availability).

Mario Kart World, the Switch 2's flagship launch game, has now sold 9.57 million copies, with 8.1 million units of that total from the console's bundle. (So yes, more than a million people paid $80 to buy it separately.)

Nintendo's second biggest Switch 2 title, Donkey Kong Bananza, has notched up 3.49 million sales since its July debut. Super Mario Party Jamboree ‚Äî Nintendo Switch 2 Edition, meanwhile, has sold 1.16 million copies.

There's no word in today's data on Pok√©mon Legends Z-A, which launched too recently to be included. However, we already know the new Pok√©mon adventure has sold 5.8 million copies in a week ‚Äî enough to ensure it will certainly be one of the console's best sellers in Nintendo's next results.

Nintendo Switch 2 System and Accessories Gallery

Interestingly, sales of Switch 1 game Mario Kart 8 Deluxe continue to remain strong ‚Äî with another 1.37 million units sold over the last six months (seriously, who doesn't own a copy by now?).

The original Nintendo Switch now stands at 154 million units, meanwhile, meaning it is just 10,000 sales away from overtaking Nintendo's current best-selling device ‚Äî the Nintendo DS. But can the aging console shift another six million units to finally dethrone the best-selling console ever, PlayStation 2? Nintendo says it expects Switch 1 to have reached a lifetime total of 156 million by the end of March 2026, so it will come close.

Tom Phillips is IGN's News Editor. You can reach Tom at tom_phillips@ign.com or find him on Bluesky @tomphillipseg.bsky.social

item.title: Dispatch has sold 1 million copies in under two weeks
item.content:encoded:
TechTarget and Informa Tech‚Äôs Digital Business Combine.TechTarget and Informa

The episodic superhero comedy features big-name actors like Aaron Paul and Jeffrey Wright.

Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

November 4, 2025

1 Min Read

Newsbrief: Superhero workplace comedy Dispatch has sold over 1 million copies in 10 days. The episodic title debuted on October 22 for PC and consoles and is developed by AdHoc Studio, which includes the writers and directors of Tales from the Borderlands and The Wolf Among Us. 

It features a stacked voice cast including Breaking Bad lead Aaron Paul and Jeffrey Wright of Westworld and The Batman fame. 

Dispatch has adopted a weekly release schedule that has seen Adhoc release two new episodes every Wednesday, starting with launch day on October 22. The eight episode season will conclude on November 12.

About the Author

Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

Game Developer news editor Chris Kerr is an award-winning reporter with over a decade of experience in the game industry. His byline has appeared in notable print and digital publications including Edge, Stuff, Wireframe, International Business Times, and PocketGamer.biz. Throughout his career, Chris has covered major industry events including GDC, PAX Australia, Gamescom, Paris Games Week, and Develop Brighton.
